newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian metals - Trading dull ahead of budget.
newsitem.headline: Indian metals - Trading dull ahead of budget.

text.p: Trading in non-ferrous metals on the Bombay Metals Exchange (BME) entered a dull phase ahead of India's national budget for 1997/98 (April/March), dealers said on Wednesday.
"Inventories are low and so are business volumes," said BME president Sharad Parikh. He did not give figures.
Parikh said the limited supplies available were mainly offered by state-owned agencies.
Dealers said most metals traders had not made any purchases abroad, expecting a reduction in import tariffs in the budget which will be unveiled on February 28.
"We are expecting an overall reduction of 5.0-10 percent in import tariffs on all non-ferrous metals," said a dealer. "But still importers are not taking any chances."
In the week to Wednesday, copper lost 50 rupees to 13,050 rupees per quintal (100 kg) and nickel gained 200 rupees to 37,200 rupees per quintal.
Stray physical support helped nickel firm, after its last week's rise of 400 rupees per quintal, dealers said.
All other metals were unchanged in dull trade.
METALS WEEKLY PRICES (in rupees per quintal)
